We are about two weeks away from the national election and I can’t stop asking myself which party I’m going to vote for.

Descriptions: They waited in anticipation for a “special guest”, as per the announcement by the host, US ambassador to South Africa Patrick Gaspard.
Articles: They waited in anticipation for a “special guest”, as per the announcement by the host, US ambassador to South Africa Patrick Gaspard. They had no idea that Oprah Winfrey was about to walk into the conference room.When the queen of TV talk shows entered from the backstage area, they erupted in joyous screams. Their Mam’ Oprah, as they affectionately call her, walked into the conference room at the Premier Hotel at OR Tambo International Airport in Ekurhuleni.One would think Winfrey is used to joyous screams from fans and audiences, but she was overwhelmed by the love that the young attendants showered her with. Almost with a South African accent, she said, “Tjo!”, reacting to the 250 girls and young women who are supported by Dreams – Determined, Resilient, Empowered, Aids-free, Mentored and Safe – a US initiative that aims to reduce new HIV infections in adolescents and young women in 10 sub-Saharan African countries, including South Africa.In South Africa, the Dreams initiative focuses on priority areas – Gauteng and KwaZulu-Natal – as these provinces have the highest HIV infection rate.In South Africa, adolescent girls (aged 15 to 19) are eight times more likely to be infected with HIV than their male counterparts. Young women (20 to 24) are three times more likely to be infected than young men of the same age group.An inspiring success story Winfrey’s life story – from growing up in an impoverished Mississippi town where she was raped at a young age, falling pregnant and losing the baby, to being the queen of talk shows with her own TV network – inspires young women to look beyond their past and difficult circumstances.Winfrey poured her heart out to the audience. She told them about her religious upbringing, which she said was her pillar and strength, and how she climbed the ladder of success.“I grew up in the church. My grandmother led me to the sense of God and made me believe there was a greater force than me. I grew up believing that God was my father and Jesus was my brother, which meant I could do anything in life.“In life you cannot trust yourself only, there must be some higher force you trust in, be it God, the community or an organisation, because you cannot be successful on your own,” she told the girls, adding that their history and past experiences – no matter how unfortunate – should not define their future.“What you do today and where you see yourself is what matters.“You need to know what kind of woman you want to be and where you want to be, not just in terms of profession, but in life. Life will lead you where you want to go ... People pay attention to people who excel and excellence is a deterrent for sexism,” Winfrey said.The audience was given an opportunity to ask questions, many of which centred on how to keep young girls motivated and what they could learn from her success story.Source: City Press
Summaries:
They waited in anticipation for a “special guest”, as per the announcement by the host, US ambassador to South Africa Patrick Gaspard.
In South Africa, the Dreams initiative focuses on priority areas – Gauteng and KwaZulu-Natal – as these provinces have the highest HIV infection rate.
In South Africa, adolescent girls (aged 15 to 19) are eight times more likely to be infected with HIV than their male counterparts.
Young women (20 to 24) are three times more likely to be infected than young men of the same age group.
The audience was given an opportunity to ask questions, many of which centred on how to keep young girls motivated and what they could learn from her success story.

Headlines: MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN: STAYING SAFE
Descriptions: My name is Malibongwe Daweti and I am 42 years old. I come from Idutywa in Xauka, Eastern Cape and I work as a community coordinator for Health Systems Trust in the OR Tambo and Chris Hani districts.
Articles: My name is Malibongwe Daweti and I am 42 years old. Icome from Idutywa in Xauka, Eastern Cape and I work as a community coordinatorfor Health Systems Trust in the OR Tambo and Chris Hani districts. Working in HIV prevention and treatment, we are awarethat there is a large at-risk group that many people don’t like to talk about.This group is men who have sex with men, also known as “MSM”. It is important to note that this is not the same asbeing gay. A gay man self-identifies as such and is “out” about his sexuality.A man who has sex with men does it “on the down low”, considers himselfheterosexual and is often married with children.The root cause of this is stigma about homosexualitywhich means these men will not disclose this, and often will not even do so withhealth professionals. Many MSM have multiple partners or pay for sex withyounger men.  Because this behaviour issecretive they are often unprepared and so do not use protection – and the realityis that anal sex is a high risk factor in terms of becoming infected with HIV. Stigma drives this issue underground.We say that homosexuality is a foreign concept thatarrived here in a ship, but we must also note that amagoduka (migrant workers) used to have such relationships in single-sexhostels, so it has been there for quite some time.  If a man does not want to tell people his sexualpreference, that is up to him. But as a man you must be brave enough to protectyour family, your loved ones and yourself. If you don’t want to disclose, thenthat is fine – but make sure you test and have safe sex.To find out more about testing, counselling and treatmentplease go to http://betteroffknowing.org.za/
Summaries:
This group is men who have sex with men, also known as “MSM”.
A gay man self-identifies as such and is “out” about his sexuality.
A man who has sex with men does it “on the down low”, considers himself heterosexual and is often married with children.
Many MSM have multiple partners or pay for sex with younger men.
If you don’t want to disclose, then that is fine – but make sure you test and have safe sex.

Headlines: A GUNMAN FORCED ME TO POKE WOMEN
Descriptions: THIS young man wants justice.
Articles: THIS young man wants justice.On Saturday night, the 28-year-old from Ivory Park near Midrand was walking to a late-night eating place when a car stopped next to him. He said he was forced into the vehicle at gunpoint. “There were two men and two women in the car.”He told Daily Sun they drove with him to an isolated spot, where he was forced to poke the two women.“The sex carried on for about 15 minutes while the man pointed a gun at me,” he said.He was then told to leave.The man went to the police station in the morning, but the cops at Ivory Park cop shop referred him to Tembisa hospital.On Monday, he was tested for HIV at Bophelong Clinic in Ivory and the results came back negative. He said when he went to open a case, a cop made him sign a form and said he was not going to open a case. Captain Bernard Matimulane said the man should open a case and lodge a complaint against the cop.
Summaries:
THIS young man wants justice.
On Saturday night, the 28-year-old from Ivory Park near Midrand was walking to a late-night eating place when a car stopped next to him.
“There were two men and two women in the car.”He told Daily Sun they drove with him to an isolated spot, where he was forced to poke the two women.
The man went to the police station in the morning, but the cops at Ivory Park cop shop referred him to Tembisa hospital.
Captain Bernard Matimulane said the man should open a case and lodge a complaint against the cop.

Descriptions: HE OFTEN heard residents from Umlazi, south of Durban, complaining about alleged corruption at Emaweleni Sassa offices.
Articles: HE OFTEN heard residents from Umlazi, south of Durban, complaining about alleged corruption at Emaweleni Sassa offices.Then he experienced it himself. The 42-year-old HIV-positive man, who also suffers from epilepsy, had applied for a disability grant. But his application was rejected.Then an official who had been helping him at the offices allegedly told him that the doctor’s decision to deny him the grant could be reversed if he paid R5 000.The unemployed man told Daily Sun that he reported the matter to the Sassa corruption unit. He also wrote letters to the KZN social development MEC, Weziwe Thusi, followed by several phone calls.“Thusi has not responded to any of my letters and phone calls,” he said. “And Sassa has failed to treat the matter with urgency, as promised.”He said at the beginning of 2014, he tested HIV-positive and was placed on treatment.“All along I had no problem until the beginning of this year when I was diagnosed with epilepsy. I was forced to quit my job as it was no longer safe for me to work.” He said he had been burnt by boiling water twice as a result of his condition.He said he suspected the problem with his application was not that he did not meet the standards.“They probably dismissed it because they were hoping their corruption would work out.”Sassa KZN spokesman Vusi Mahaye said: “Investigations are continuing.”Social development spokesman Vukani Mbhele said: “We are going to liaise with Sassa to find a solution to this man’s problem.”
Summaries:
HE OFTEN heard residents from Umlazi, south of Durban, complaining about alleged corruption at Emaweleni Sassa offices.
Then an official who had been helping him at the offices allegedly told him that the doctor’s decision to deny him the grant could be reversed if he paid R5 000.
The unemployed man told Daily Sun that he reported the matter to the Sassa corruption unit.
He also wrote letters to the KZN social development MEC, Weziwe Thusi, followed by several phone calls.
“Thusi has not responded to any of my letters and phone calls,” he said.

Descriptions: IN DECEMBER 2012, Dikeledi Mehlape (16) was raped, stabbed, strangled and had her breasts cut off to “strengthen love”.    That was the belief held by her now convicted killer Maretsane Phoshoko (23).
Articles: IN DECEMBER 2012, Dikeledi Mehlape (16) was raped, stabbed, strangled and had her breasts cut off to “strengthen love”. That was the belief held by her now convicted killer Maretsane Phoshoko (23). He was the boyfriend of Dikeledi’s childhood friend and convicted accomplice, Lerato Maenetja (17). Dikeledi was killed by Phoshoko as Maenetja watched. The murder in Ga-Mothapo, Limpopo was one of several case studies presented at the Gender Equality Assessment. The event was presented by deputy social development minister Hendrietta Bogopane-Zulu in Tshwane yesterday.var randomAdNumber = Math.floor((Math.random() * 50000) + 99000000);document.write(""); The assessment looked at the impact of coming-of-age cultural practices on the rights of girls and young women. It also asked whether such practices increased the risk of HIV infection, unwanted pregnancies and gender-based violence. Dikeledi’s mother, Lebogang Mehlape, tearfully recounted the family’s trauma to highlight the continued battle against violence against women. Earlier, at a specially convened media briefing, Bogopane-Zulu shed light on several cultural practices that were found to have impacted negatively on stopping HIV infection, unwanted pregnancies and gender-based violence. Woman-on-woman violence was discussed. Fights between mothers-in-law and daughters-in-law play a key role here. Regarding lobola, Bogopane-Zulu said: “Traditional leaders are saying it has become a commercial practice that contributes to gender-based violence.” But not all cultural practices have negative outcomes. Virginity testing and sexual counselling, for example, form part of natural support systems that can help to prevent the spread of HIV and girls being raped, Bogopane-Zulu said. Assessments were done in the Eastern Cape, Mpumalanga and KZN.- Daily Sun
Summaries:
The assessment looked at the impact of coming-of-age cultural practices on the rights of girls and young women.
It also asked whether such practices increased the risk of HIV infection, unwanted pregnancies and gender-based violence.
Earlier, at a specially convened media briefing, Bogopane-Zulu shed light on several cultural practices that were found to have impacted negatively on stopping HIV infection, unwanted pregnancies and gender-based violence.
Regarding lobola, Bogopane-Zulu said: “Traditional leaders are saying it has become a commercial practice that contributes to gender-based violence.”But not all cultural practices have negative outcomes.
Virginity testing and sexual counselling, for example, form part of natural support systems that can help to prevent the spread of HIV and girls being raped, Bogopane-Zulu said.

Descriptions: HUNDREDS of maidens from different parts of KZN marched to the office of Premier Willies Mchunu on Wednesday.
Articles: HUNDREDS of maidens from different parts of KZN marched to the office of Premier Willies Mchunu on Wednesday. They said they were there to show their anger over a UN statement last month calling for virginity testing to be stopped. Thokozani Ngcobo (27) said the UN didn’t even consult them. “We are here to send a message to the government that we will shut down South Africa if they ban virginity testing,” she said. Slindile Ngobese (23) said she was part of the march to fight for her rights. “We are here because it is our choice to participate in virginity testing,” she said. Cultural expert and virginity tester Nomagugu Ngobese said they would continue with the practice. “We appeal to other countries to stop interfering in our culture because we will resist and fight for what we believe is right.” Ngobese said the UN should be focusing on serious issues like domestic violence, the distribution of condoms at school, teenage pregnancy, abortion and an increase in new HIV infections.Siyabonga Mnqayi from the office of the premier accepted their memorandum. “The premier is also championing social cohesion programmes.“On his behalf, we accept this memorandum with warm hands and we promise the premier will make sure it reaches the hands of the president,” said Mnqayi.
Summaries:
HUNDREDS of maidens from different parts of KZN marched to the office of Premier Willies Mchunu on Wednesday.
They said they were there to show their anger over a UN statement last month calling for virginity testing to be stopped.
“We are here to send a message to the government that we will shut down South Africa if they ban virginity testing,” she said.
“We are here because it is our choice to participate in virginity testing,” she said.
“On his behalf, we accept this memorandum with warm hands and we promise the premier will make sure it reaches the hands of the president,” said Mnqayi.

Headlines: Zuluboy brings new rules to hip hop game!
Descriptions: ZULUBOY has given newmeaning to the term game changer in the hip hop and music industry.   While some rappers are busy hurling diss tracks at each other, Zuluboy is working to become a champion of people living with disabilities.
Articles: Zuluboy introduced a sign language interpreter to his shows. ZULUBOY has given newmeaning to the term game changer in the hip hop and music industry. While some rappers are busy hurling diss tracks at each other, Zuluboy is working to become a champion of people living with disabilities. The star, whose real name is Mxolisi Majozi, has introduced a sign language interpreter for his performances. The multi-award winner has graced stages in Europe, North America and Mzansi. Zuluboy is famous for his music and lyrics which tackle a wide range of topics – from xenophobia to human trafficking and HIV/Aids. And now this bold move! This Gold Diggers star took many by surprise and wonadmiration when he introduced sign interpreter, Andiswa Majozi,during his performance atMoshito’s The Great SouthAfrican Song Book Festival atJozi’s Newtown Park performance on 12 September. Although there weren’t many people to witness the event,influential industry players and international guests were inattendance. After opening up his short set of two tracks with a group of Zulu gumboot dancers, he then invited the young lady, who also happens to be his wife, to join him to do his track Nomalanga. “We need to include people with disabilities in our engagements. “They too are part of us and have to enjoy life like we all do,” he said. The star continuously reinvents himself and has confessed heenjoys challenges and things that have meaning in his life and that of others. Apart from his role as Big Boy on Gold Diggers, alongside acting legend Mbongeni Ngema, Zuluboy has now made a mark for himself as an on-screen personality of note with appearances on Rhythm City, Mshika-shika, Soul City, Room 9, and as presenter of Fan Base.
Summaries:
ZULUBOY has given newmeaning to the term game changer in the hip hop and music industry.
While some rappers are busy hurling diss tracks at each other, Zuluboy is working to become a champion of people living with disabilities.
The star, whose real name is Mxolisi Majozi, has introduced a sign language interpreter for his performances.
Zuluboy is famous for his music and lyrics which tackle a wide range of topics – from xenophobia to human trafficking and HIV/Aids.
The star continuously reinvents himself and has confessed heenjoys challenges and things that have meaning in his life and that of others.

Headlines: MALEMA: RAMAPHOSA IS NOT A LEADER BUT A DEAL MAKER
Descriptions: President Cyril Ramaphosa isn't a leader, but a dealmaker who became president to meet white leaders and clinch deals with them, Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) leader Julius Malema said.
Articles: President Cyril Ramaphosa isn't a leader, but a dealmaker who became president to meet white leaders and clinch deals with them, Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) leader Julius Malema said.Speaking at the party's Africa Day celebration event in Sunnyside in Tshwane on Friday, Malema said Ramaphosa became president to go around the world and make deals with white leaders - not to help the people of South Africa. "Cyril doesn't need a salary. He took that position because of deal making," Malema said. "He wants to go around the world making deals. That's why he wants to be president... He doesn't want to be president for the poor. He doesn't want to be president for the HIV patients." "He wants to be president so that he can have access to white leaders and then they clinch deals. He is not a leader, he is a dealmaker. That's who is he is." Malema added that white people said Ramaphosa was the best president and that everyone else believed it. "White people want us to believe that we have got our saviour, we've got an engine; Cyril Ramaphosa is coming to save us." Malema added that Ramaphosa should be rejected for what he did to people in Marikana and for buying a buffalo for R18m. He said the president should also be rejected for giving half of his presidential salary to a new Madiba fund, saying it was a "misdirected type of intervention.""The money must go to the squatter camps. The money must go to the landless people. The money must go to the unemployed people. The money must go to the children of the domestic workers. That's where we need this money." Malema also criticised those who applauded Ramaphosa for the move. "You all clap hands as if he is the masterpiece, but this man is worth billions. Why can't he take half of what he is worth and give it to the poor? Why can't he take half a billion and give it to the poor?" Speaking about Africa Day, Malema said it's a day in which Africans can celebrate themselves and tell the world that they are Africans and proud of their heritage. "We are not ashamed of being African. We are not ashamed of being black." He told the crowd that South Africans should be gathering on Africa Day, which should be a public holiday, to remind themselves of who they are and where they come from. In addition, he said that South Africans should welcome people from other African countries as the Khoi and the San once welcomed Africans from the north who travelled to Southern Africa to settle. "None of us are from here, we come from the north and found the Khoi and the San when we settled here. The Khoi and the San welcomed us here. We should welcome others here the same way we were welcomed here." Malema promised that the EFF would rename South Africa and call it Azania.  "South Africa, we still don't have a name until today because South Africa is not a name. It's a direction." "We need a name for this beautiful country and that name will be given to this country by the EFF when we take over power in 2019. This country shall be declared Azania." Before concluding his speech, Malema called on his supporters to register for the 2019 national elections.  "Next year there [are] elections. Let's go and take this government. Go register because registration means you are armed and registration is a weapon that will be used to destroy the ANC."News24  Sourcehttps://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/ramaphosa-not-a-leader-but-a-dealmaker-malema-20180525
Summaries: MALEMA: RAMAPHOSA IS NOT A LEADER BUT A DEAL MAKER

Headlines: GIRLS WARNED TO ABSTAIN FROM SEX
Descriptions: MEMBERS of the Maliyavuza Ubuhle Bengcunce cultural governance group meet every month to celebrate the ancient cultural practice.
Articles: MEMBERS of the Maliyavuza Ubuhle Bengcunce cultural governance group meet every month to celebrate the ancient cultural practice.Dozens of girls lined-up in Tsakane, Ekurhuleni at the weekend, ready to go through ukuhlolwa (virginity inspection).The organisation performs virginity tests to make sure that young girls don’t indulge in sex at an early age.The process also involves teaching them life skills and how to handle themselves as women.var randomAdNumber = Math.floor((Math.random() * 50000) + 99000000);document.write("");They are encouraged to take pride in their virginity. Young parents are also given tips on how to take care of their children.More than 500 girls from all over Gauteng as well as other provinces are members of the organisation that was founded in 2012.Founder Maliyavuza Buhle (46) said the organisation aims to preserve the culture and heritage practices our forefathers left for us.“There were too many misconceptions around the cultural practice. “However, African people have been practising virginity testing for centuries,” she said.“We encourage abstinence and sexual responsibility among unmarried young women. “The practice also helps curb teenage pregnancy and the spread of HIV/Aids.” Nomfundo Ngubane (21) – who passed her virginity test – said her parents were proud of her.“They are happy that I have a great respect for my body,” said Nomfundo. - Daily Sun
Summaries:
MEMBERS of the Maliyavuza Ubuhle Bengcunce cultural governance group meet every month to celebrate the ancient cultural practice.
Dozens of girls lined-up in Tsakane, Ekurhuleni at the weekend, ready to go through ukuhlolwa (virginity inspection).
The organisation performs virginity tests to make sure that young girls don’t indulge in sex at an early age.
Young parents are also given tips on how to take care of their children.
More than 500 girls from all over Gauteng as well as other provinces are members of the organisation that was founded in 2012.

Articles: ZUMA IS DOOMED PARTY'S ALBATROSSHistorians will put it on record that, on the day before Women’s Day last week, ANC MPs in their majority voted to retain their president.They voted for a man, who in 2005 faced a rape trial while heading the National Aids Council, who admitted to unprotected sex with someone he knew to be HIV-positive and who told the world he took a shower to reduce the risk of HIV.One can mark that day last week as the day when the nail finally was driven into the ANC’s coffin.The stand taken by 26 MPs who voted for the motion, those abstaining and those who absented themselves must be applauded.They did this in obedience to their consciences, realising the #Guptaleaks evoked a lukewarm response from Luthuli House.Those voting against them ensured the man whose friends are the Guptas stays in office.The Gupta empire spans computer equipment, media and mining and they have given the president’s family shares and senior positions.The Guptas and the president’s son Duduzane have the power to hire and fire ministers. Those who report corruption lose their jobs.The 2013 Gupta wedding party was also paid for by South African taxpayers, courtesy of KPMG.ANC members are being called upon to carry their albatross Zuma around their necks and so condemn their organisation to death.

ZUMA IS DOOMED PARTY'S ALBATROSSHistorians will put it on record that, on the day before Women’s Day last week, ANC MPs in their majority voted to retain their president.They voted for a man, who in 2005 faced a rape trial while heading the National Aids Council, who admitted to unprotected sex with someone he knew to be HIV-positive and who told the world he took a shower to reduce the risk of HIV.One can mark that day last week as the day when the nail finally was driven into the ANC’s coffin.The stand taken by 26 MPs who voted for the motion, those abstaining and those who absented themselves must be applauded.They did this in obedience to their consciences, realising the #Guptaleaks evoked a lukewarm response from Luthuli House.Those voting against them ensured the man whose friends are the Guptas stays in office.The Gupta empire spans computer equipment, media and mining and they have given the president’s family shares and senior positions.The Guptas and the president’s son Duduzane have the power to hire and fire ministers. Those who report corruption lose their jobs.The 2013 Gupta wedding party was also paid for by South African taxpayers, courtesy of KPMG.ANC members are being called upon to carry their albatross Zuma around their necks and so condemn their organisation to death.

Headlines: CRISELDA SAYS SORRY FOR HER COMMENTS
Descriptions: CRISELDA Kananda-Dudumashe has apologised for defending Mduduzi Manana.
Articles: CRISELDA Kananda-Dudumashe has apologised for defending Mduduzi Manana.She made comments on her Instagram page about Manana, who has resigned as deputy minister of higher education after assaulting a woman at a nightclub in Joburg.Criselda also said sorry about comments she made around the LGBTI community while speaking at a gender-based violence dialogue at the University of Venda in Limpopo last week. In a statement issued yesterday, Criselda, a Metro FM radio host, said she has accepted the public criticism directed at her.var randomAdNumber = Math.floor((Math.random() * 50000) + 99000000);document.write("");“I recognise that my statements have caused harm, for which I am deeply sorry.“I have noted objections by organisations such as the Treatment Action Campaign to my nomination to serve on the board of the SA National Aids Trust,” she said. She said she’s taken the decision to decline nomination to serve on the trust. “The objections are based on statements I believe will constitute conflict of interest if I were to serve on the trust.” She has already been relieved of her duties as an ambassador by the Higher Education and Training HIV/Aids programme.“Hopefully, this decision, which I have communicated to the office of the deputy president, will remove all the controversy surrounding my nomination.” Criselda first made comments about Manana on her Instagram page.She wrote about how she had known him personally and had worked with him on government projects aimed at educating the youth.- Daily Sun
Summaries:
She made comments on her Instagram page about Manana, who has resigned as deputy minister of higher education after assaulting a woman at a nightclub in Joburg.
Criselda also said sorry about comments she made around the LGBTI community while speaking at a gender-based violence dialogue at the University of Venda in Limpopo last week.
In a statement issued yesterday, Criselda, a Metro FM radio host, said she has accepted the public criticism directed at her.
“I recognise that my statements have caused harm, for which I am deeply sorry.
“Hopefully, this decision, which I have communicated to the office of the deputy president, will remove all the controversy surrounding my nomination.”Criselda first made comments about Manana on her Instagram page.

Descriptions: THOLOKWAKHE Sithole wants his passengers to be safe in his taxi – and in bed!  So he gives them condoms and tells them to take care of themselves.
Articles: Driver Tholokwakhe Sithole cares a lot about his clients, providing them with protection every day.                  Photo by Zamokuhle Mdluli THOLOKWAKHE Sithole wants his passengers to be safe in his taxi – and in bed! So he gives them condoms and tells them to take care of themselves. Tholokwakhe (27), of Soweto’s Dube Hostel, said many people find getting condoms at clinics embarrassing.  “So they risk their lives with unprotected sex.  “I’m doing this to save them,” he said. The kind Phefeni Association taxi driver said he was sad that people were still dying of HIV/Aids while there are free condoms at clinics. Every day after work he collects two boxes of condoms from a clinic in Dube to hand out. “I don’t care what people say when they see my dashboard full of condoms,” he said.  “I know what my aim is.” Passenger Sonny Deriche (25), who was given condoms yesterday morning, said: “When you go to the clinic everyone looks at you.  “You know what they think – that this guy is going to get some today! It kills your mood. It’s why we stay away from clinics,” he said. Gauteng Health spokesman Steve Mabona praised Tholokwakhe. “We need people like him in our country,” he said. “Maybe there might be something else he can do for us. We need to speak to him,” he said.
Summaries:
THOLOKWAKHE Sithole wants his passengers to be safe in his taxi – and in bed!
So he gives them condoms and tells them to take care of themselves.
Tholokwakhe (27), of Soweto’s Dube Hostel, said many people find getting condoms at clinics embarrassing.
The kind Phefeni Association taxi driver said he was sad that people were still dying of HIV/Aids while there are free condoms at clinics.
Every day after work he collects two boxes of condoms from a clinic in Dube to hand out.

Headlines: Dingaan dishes the dirt and Tsholo takes offence
Descriptions: SPEAK OUT host, Dingaan Mokebe ka Khumalo, and his ex-girlfriend, Tsholofelo Matshaba, aired their dirty laundry live on Kaya FM last week!
Articles: SPEAK OUT host, Dingaan Mokebe ka Khumalo, and his ex-girlfriend, Tsholofelo Matshaba, aired their dirty laundry live on Kaya FM last week! Dingaan was on a live show, Home with Mapaseka Mokwele, on Tuesday – to talk about men who are denied access to their children.The Muvhango actor, who plays James, alleged Tsholo hasn’t allowed him to see his daughter since 2010. He said he stopped paying papgeld in 2011 and added his attorneys have been struggling to reach Tsholo.But during Wednesday’s show an angry Tsholo snapped back.She told Mapaseka and the listeners: “He (Dingaan) was given a chance to be on the show in the child’s best interest. But instead he took that platform to assassinate my character and spread lies about me not allowing him access to the child.”Her manager and husband Chris Matshaba told Sunday Sun: “We had to fight for Tsholo to be able to give her side on the show. I contacted Mapaseka and her producer, asking them to give her the same opportunity he got.“Dingaan has never been denied an opportunity to see his child. We’re talking about two people who don’t know each other. She calls me papa.”Chris claimed: “Dingaan is lying about trying to reach Tsholo and not getting hold of her. He knows where she lives and knows where her parents stay.“They’re upset to have been dragged into this.”He alleged every year, Dingaan runs to the media without calling Tsholo.“He’s afraid to talk to her as he used to beat her up. When I met her she was not okay. She had to go through counselling and was traumatised by all the damage he had caused. It took her a year to heal,” claimed Chris.He said he has no issues with Dingaan, but he needs to respect Tsholo, his daughter and the rest of the family.This week Dingaan said: “I spoke too much about these things. I don’t have anything to say any more.”Tsholo said what Dingaan’s doing is annoying.“It bleeds through to my new family. I have to account for his lies to my husband and my family.“He’s scared to face me as he used to physically abuse me while we were dating. What kind of a dad is he who wants to be reminded of his responsibilities?” she said.
Summaries:
“He’s scared to face me as he used to physically abuse me while we were dating.
What kind of a dad is he who wants to be reminded of his responsibilities?” she said.
“It bleeds through to my new family.
I have to account for his lies to my husband and my family.

Descriptions: THERE has been no rest for Idols SA winner Karabo Mogane after winning the lucrative M-Net contest last Sunday.
Articles: THERE has been no rest for Idols SA winner Karabo Mogane after winning the lucrative M-Net contest last Sunday. The winner from Mbombela, in Mpumalanga, is currently busy in studio creating music for his debut album, which is set to be released this December.This will be the first time an Idols SA winner releases an album just weeks after winning, and just in time for Christmas. Karabo also hit the ground running when he secured his first gig before even releasing an album.He’ll be performing at the annual HIV/Aids Benefit Concert which will be held at Abrahsmsrust, in Fezile Dabi District Municipality.Karabo will also get to attend next year’s American Idols finale in Los Angeles, in the US. Speaking to Sunday Sun at the Universal Music studio, Karabo said the album is taking shape quite nicely. “We’re doing about three tracks a day and hope to finish recording in the next few days,” he said.
Summaries:
THERE has been no rest for Idols SA winner Karabo Mogane after winning the lucrative M-Net contest last Sunday.
This will be the first time an Idols SA winner releases an album just weeks after winning, and just in time for Christmas.
Karabo also hit the ground running when he secured his first gig before even releasing an album.
Karabo will also get to attend next year’s American Idols finale in Los Angeles, in the US.
Speaking to Sunday Sun at the Universal Music studio, Karabo said the album is taking shape quite nicely.

Descriptions: SOMIZI has become the first Mzansi celeb to announce he will not be supporting Mampintsha and his music.
Articles: SOMIZI has become the first Mzansi celeb to announce he will not be supporting Mampintsha and his music. Speakingduring his “Woo Shem” moment on The Fresh Breakfast show on Metro FM, Somizisaid he was booked by Mampintsha for an event in May.“I can say now I ampulling out. I am pulling out. I cannot be part of this. I am not going to keepquiet and support it. I am so angry right now,” Somizi said. Without even mentioningit, Somizi gave the impression that he was calling on other celebs and peoplein the industry to cancel Mampintsha and not support his gig or music. Somizi’scomments come after a video of Mampintsha beating Babes Wodumo surfaced earliertoday. In the video, Mampintsha can be seen repeatedly hitting and dragging the Gqom Queen violently.
Summaries:
SOMIZI has become the first Mzansi celeb to announce he will not be supporting Mampintsha and his music.
Speaking during his “Woo Shem” moment on The Fresh Breakfast show on Metro FM, Somizi said he was booked by Mampintsha for an event in May.
Without even mentioning it, Somizi gave the impression that he was calling on other celebs and people in the industry to cancel Mampintsha and not support his gig or music.
Somizi’s comments come after a video of Mampintsha beating Babes Wodumo surfaced earlier today.
In the video, Mampintsha can be seen repeatedly hitting and dragging the Gqom Queen violently.
